content.webTitle: In praise of … David Rosenberg | Editorial

fields.headline: In praise of … David Rosenberg
fields.bodyText: For a professional voyeur, David Rosenberg certainly puts his back into his work. Consider his latest show, Electric Hotel. Audience members sit in a glorified car park in front of a four-storey hotel, where seven dancers in different rooms enact their own sad melodramas. In one box, a couple row and flirt over and over again. In another, a man in his underwear plays air guitar. Up top is a nightclub. Periodically, maids clean up, a dispatch rider brings in a mysterious package – and a scream jolts staff and guests out of their reveries. This is uneasy eavesdropping – and for co-director Rosenberg and his crew it is also hard graft. Electric Hotel is that rare bird: a site-specific show that tours (it's been to Norfolk and is now in London before heading to Stockton). It also has that Rosenbergian experimentation with sound – audience members clamp on headphones that pipe in stray laughter, distorted music and menacing phrases. The son of a physiologist, Rosenberg has collaborated with neuroscientists to explore how audience focus can be manipulated by the use of sound. And as a founding member of the experimental theatre collective Shunt, he has put on pieces influenced by Rear Window and Twin Peaks – but which also take their cue from Brecht's work in audience alienation. Now 40, he draws a younger crowd that would normally go out dancing, not watch it. Yet his work is stylish and suggestive, creating an atmosphere that stays with audiences – and troubles them too. One to watch.
